Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Victorian Music Hall audience have enjoyed the performance. Cries of bravo! as the curtain falls on the Chinese magician and his dummy, and assistant. Backstage, he is met by the owner, an ebullient chap with a large cigar in his hand and a red rose in his buttonhole.

Dialogue.Line: Mister Chang. Wonderful, wonderful. Words fail me, sir. Words quite fail me.
You are most generous.
Have I ever, in my thirty years in the halls, seen such a dazzling display of lustrous legerdemain? So many feats of superlative, supernatural skill? The answer must be never, sir. Never.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chang displays his ventriloquism.

Dialogue.Line: Honourable master is kind to bestow praise on humble Chang's miserable, unworthy head.
Dashed clever, the way you work the little fellow. Wires in the sleeves, I dare say. But I'll not pry, Mister Chang. The secrets of the artistes are sacrosanct.
Hey, you!
What the deuce?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The stage doorkeeper is holding back an agitated young man, wearing a cabbie's licence number 14305.

Dialogue.Line: Where's my Emma? What have you done with her?
You've got no right to burst in here.
Out of my way! It's him I want.
Your Emma?
She come in here last night and nobody ain't seen her since.
I'll have the fellow ejected.
Now I'm asking you, mister, what's happened to her?
Call the stage hands, Freddy.
It's all right, Mister Jago. Please, come with me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chang leads the young man away.

Dialogue.Line: Courteous coves, these Chinese. I'd have propelled him onto the pavement with a punt up the posterior.
Your wife?
Emma Buller. And don't deny she was here, cos I saw her with my own eyes.
Many ladies come to theatre. Why should you think

Not round the side door, they don't. Now, look. I was passing in my cab and I saw her plain, and I know it was you she was calling on. She's been acting queer ever since you put the 'fluence on her last week, so don't try coming the innocent, Mister. I want to know where she is or I'm calling the law. Clear?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chang's assistant helps him off with his stage robe.

Dialogue.Line: Your wife came on stage?
Last week. Levitated her, you did. She's not been the same since. It's done something to her reason, I shouldn't wonder. And she was here last night.
Not to see me.
Don't come the cod. She's disappeared. Nobody's seen her, not since she come here last night, so what about it, eh?
In my country we have saying. Man who goes too quickly may step in bear trap.
Right, I'm getting the Peelers. (Buller leaves. Chang looks at the dummy, Sin, who nods.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Tardis materialises on a pathway by the Thames down in the East End, probably near the East India Docks. Leela steps out dressed in a Victorian boy's outfit.

Dialogue.Line: These clothes are ridiculous. Why must I wear them?
Because you can't go walking around Victorian London in skins. You'll frighten the horses.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor emerges in deerstalker and Argyll cape.

Dialogue.Line: Anyway, we don't want to be conspicuous, do we?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A foghorn sounds. The Doctor looks at an advertising poster for H'sen Chang's act of magic and mesmerism.

Dialogue.Line: A swamp creature. That was it's attack cry.
Oh no, it was a ship on the river. Excellent. It means we can't be far away.
From where?
From where we're going.
Doctor, you make me wear strange clothes, you tell me nothing. You are trying to annoy me.

I'm trying to teach you, Leela. Surely you'd like to see how your ancestors enjoyed themselves? Splendid. That's why I'm taking you to the theatre. Li H'sen Chang. Hmm, pity. I'd rather hoped we'd catch Little Tich. Never mind. If we hurry we'll just catch the second house.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jago speaks to a dance girl walking past.

Dialogue.Line: You'd better get your tail pinned on. Linens up in five minutes. Casey, have you got the oopizootics coming on?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: An Irishman comes up the ladder from under the stage and staggers towards him.

Dialogue.Line: Mister Jago, I've seen it. I've seen it again!
Be quiet. I told you before.
Horrible, horrible it was, Mister Jago. A great skull coming at me out of the dark.
Damme, you don't want to bankrupt me, Casey. Keep your voice down. Threadbare in Carey Street I'll be if people get the notion there's anything wrong with this theatre.
Chains clanking, nine foot tall.
You've been drinking.
Not a drop, sir.
Well, it's time you started.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jago holds out his hip flask. Casey takes a long pull.

Dialogue.Line: Now pull yourself together, man.
I ain't never going down that cellar again. There I was, fixing the trap, when this apparition rose out of the ground in front of me. Hideous, it was. Hideous.
That's enough.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jago takes his flask back.

Dialogue.Line: It's your imagination.
Never.

A cat or something must be trapped down there making noises. Tell you what I'll do, Casey. I'll come down with you this evening, as soon as the house is clear, and we'll have a good look round. Now how's that?
It was no cat, Mister Jago. I seen it!
Please, Casey, remember, mum's the word.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: In an alleyway behind the theatre, young Buller is confronted by Mister Sin the ventriloquist's dummy, wielding a knife. Meanwhile...

Dialogue.Line: This is a big village.
Yes.
What's the name of the tribe here?
Cockneys.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They hear a man scream.

Dialogue.Line: The sound of death!
You stay here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He walks on to see a group men struggling with a one on the ground.

Dialogue.Line: Excuse me, can I help you?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The men attack him. They are Chinese. Leela runs in to help but is no real match for their karate or whatever. Then a policeman's whistle sounds. The Chinese run off, carrying the man. The Doctor trips up the last one and Leela pounces on him.. The Doctor chases the others. There is the sound of a steam train.

Dialogue.Line: Hold you there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor runs back to Leela. The police have arrived.

Dialogue.Line: Now then, what's all this?
Touch me and I'll break your arm.
Now don't be foolish, miss.
Good evening.
Keep back, Doctor. Blue guards!
Good evening, Constable.
Good evening, sir. You know this young female, sir?
Oh yes, yes. We were attacked by this little man and four other little men.
When I got here, sir, he was being strangled with his own pigtail, sir.
Really? Girlish enthusiasm, officer?
You might call it that, sir. I call it making an affray. I must ask you to come down the station with me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chang has successfully got a young lady suspended in mid air between two chairs.

Dialogue.Line: Please to see, ladies and gentlemen, subject now in state of deep hypnosis.
Oh!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chang picks up Sin.

Dialogue.Line: She asleep.
She not asleep, Mister Sin.
She been slugging type of toddy.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Laughter.

Dialogue.Line: I will prove young lady not asleep.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chang's assistant removes the chair from under the woman's ankles.

Dialogue.Line: She's lying on metal bar.
Not lying on metal bar.
I've seen it done before.
I will prove young lady not lying on metal bar.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The assistant carefully removes the chair from under her head. She hangs in mid air.

Dialogue.Line: She's held up by wires.
Enough.
You can't fool me.
Silence!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chang puts the dummy down on the chair and gets a samurai sword which he brandishes round it.

Dialogue.Line: Don't touch me! Help! Police! Murder!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chang waves the sword around the woman.

Dialogue.Line: You see? No wires, Mister Sin. I will now demonstrate art of levitation raising most beautiful lady high above own topknot.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The woman rises in the air, and Chang steps forward underneath her. From the wings, Jago notices blood trickling down Sin's hand.
The Sergeant is taking down particulars.

Dialogue.Line: Name, sir?
Doctor. Leela.
Place of residence, sir?
We've only just arrived here.
We're on our way to the theatre, do you see.
Your home address will do for the moment, sir. You do have a permanent address, sir?
No, Sergeant. We're travellers.
I see. Persons of no fixed abode.
No, no, no, no. We do have an abode. It's called a Tardis.
A Tardis.
But it's not fixed.
I can give you and the young lady a fixed abode, sir. Quite easily.
Flat footed imbecile.
What was that, sir?
It was nothing complementary. Get on with it, Sergeant.
Now look, sir. We've got our hands full here, all these girls going missing in the manor, so if you'd just oblige us by answering any questions we'll get on a lot better. And a lot quicker.
Sergeant, all this is irrelevant. I've come here to lay evidence.
We'll come to that in good time.
We'll come to that now, Sergeant. We've just prevented a kidnapping, a robbery or even a murder. My friend here caught one of the attackers. Let's come to it now, shall we?
We've only your word as to what he did, Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Chinaman is sitting very still at a table nearby.

Dialogue.Line: Tell him. Tell him.
The man they were carrying was dead. He had been stabbed through the heart!
Really, Miss. And how can you be sure of that?
I am a warrior of the Sevateem. I know the different sounds of death. Now put our prisoner to the torture!
Well, if that don't take the biscuit. Torture, eh? This isn't the Dark Ages, you know.
Make him talk.
He's a Chinese, if you hadn't noticed. We get a lot of those in here, Limehouse being so close. Him jaw-jaw plenty by and by, eh, Johnny? I've sent for an interpreter.
That won't be necessary. I speak Mandarin, Cantonese, all the dialects.
Oh yes?
Yes. Ne how ma? Ni chi mao cora (and so on)
Yeah, very remarkable, I'm sure, Doctor, but since you're a party to the case, it isn't proper.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A police whistle blows outside.

Dialogue.Line: Now what? That come from the river.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A raggedy old lady is pointing to a body floating face down in the Thames.

Dialogue.Line: Look, there it is, guv. See? Look.
Hurry with that boat hook.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Another constable comes down the steps with a lantern and the boat hook.

Dialogue.Line: It's a floater, all right. You've got it, guv.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The two policemen pull the body onto the shingle.

Dialogue.Line: On my oath, you wouldn't want that served with onions. Never seen anything like it in all my puff. Oh, make an 'orse sick, that would.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chang enters, dressed in Western gentleman's clothing.

Dialogue.Line: Good of you to come so prompt, sir.
Not at all, Sergeant. I'm always happy to be of service to the police. What can I do for you this time?
A complaint against this man, sir. The lady and gentleman here swear they saw him, in concert with others not in custody, carrying what appeared to be a body, sir.
Indeed.
A European body as I understand them, sir.
What happened to the others?
They got away. I caught this one.
You caught him? Remarkable.
Don't I know you?
I think not.
Yes, I've seen you somewhere before.
I understand we all look the same.
Are you Chinese? Yes, that's it. We must have. No, I haven't been in China for four hundred years.
Are you taking this matter seriously, Sergeant?
We are, sir. Will you question the man, sir?
Very well.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chang sits down opposite the prisoner.

Dialogue.Line: Can I have paper and pencil, please, Sergeant?
Certainly, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chang opens a signet ring on his gloved hand, and a small red pill rolls out. The Chinaman reaches across and picks it up, then puts it in his mouth. The Sergeant returns with a writing pad.

Dialogue.Line: Got it! Li H'sen Chang.
What?
The Master of Magic and Mesmerism. Show us a trick.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The prisoner suddenly gasps, stands, then falls across the table.

Dialogue.Line: Very good. Very good.
I think he's dead, sir.
How did you do it?
I did nothing. What are you suggesting.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor sniffs the prisoner's hand.

Dialogue.Line: Scorpion venom.
Scorpion venom?
Highly concentrated scorpion venom. It killed him almost instantly.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor points to a tattoo on the prisoner's hand.

Dialogue.Line: The Tong of the Black Scorpion.
Don't know that one, sir.
One of the most dangerous politico-criminal organisations in the world. Wouldn't you agree, Li H'sen Chang?
You seem remarkably well-informed, Doctor. Alas, I know nothing of these matters. Most regrettable incident. Goodnight, Sergeant.
Thank you, sir.
I'm sure we shall meet again.
Yes.
Perhaps under more pleasant circumstances.
Well, I don't know what to do about this lot.
Then I'll tell you what to do, Sergeant. Organise a post-mortem. I want an analysis of the organs.
You want what, sir?
Well naturally I'm going to help. If the Tong of the Black Scorpion's here in London, you're going to need all the help you can get. Now cut along and do as I say. Now!
Yes, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chang is rattling along the cobbled street.

Dialogue.Line: Faster, man, faster.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They pass a poster for the Evening Star newspaper - Missing girls mystery 8th victim.

Dialogue.Line: Twinkle, twinkle, out in front.
Eh?
Gallery lights still burning.
I'll just go and see to them now, Mister Jago.
Everyone gone?
Aye, just locked up, sir.
I hope those girls go straight home to their digs.
Oh, that they will, sir, with all this in the papers. Nine are missing now, you know.
Nine. There was some fellow in here earlier blaming Chang of all people for some girl's disappearance.
Just vanished off the streets, they have. Mostly in this area, too. What do you think's happened to them, Mister Jago?
Nothing good, Casey, nothing good. That's a stone certainty.
Oh, it says in the paper how it could be jolly Jack at work again.
Jolly Jack?
The Ripper, Mister Jago.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Which dates this story after 1888, then.

Dialogue.Line: The horrendous hyperbole of Grub Street, Casey.
Eh?
Newspaper gossip. They're probably just stony and scarpered. Cut along now. I'll wait for you here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jago goes up the stairs and sneaks in. He goes over to a wicker trunk and opens it to reveal Mister Sin the supposed ventriloquist's dummy inside. He touches it and it's eye opens then shuts again. Jago lifts the left arm.

Dialogue.Line: I was right. It was blood. Blood all over the hand and wrist. How did that get there?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Footsteps outside.

Dialogue.Line: Ready, Mister Jago.
Oh, Casey. Don't ever do that to me again. If the celestial Chang caught me trying to pinch his tricks. I had an idea that his dummy was a midget dressed up, but it's just an ordinary vent's doll.
Are we going to look down the cellar, Mister Jago?
Of course, Casey. Of course. When I promise to do something. Determination, character. After you.
They're what's known as a very dangerous bunch. Fanatical followers of an ancient Chinese god called Weng-Chiang.
The Tong of the Black Scorpion?
Yes. His followers believe that one day he'll come back and rule the world.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There are noises nearby.

Dialogue.Line: So what's he like, this Weng-Chiang?
Oh, very pleasant company. They say he blew poisonous fumes from his mouth and that he killed men with a white light that shone from his eyes.
Magic!
Superstitious rubbish. Here we are.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They go inside the Limehouse mortuary and Coroner's court. A Chinaman creeps up to the window and looks in.

Dialogue.Line: They're in there now, sir.
Taken from the river not half an hour ago. Professor Litefoot's conducting his examination now, sir.
Yes, well, our case is much more urgent.
I wouldn't go in there if I was you, sir.
Don't you worry about it. Don't you worry.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Professor has placed a specimen in a jar.

Dialogue.Line: Thank you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: And hands it to the Doctor, who puts it on a table.

Dialogue.Line: Who the devil are you, sir.
I'm the Doctor, come to help you.
When I need anyone's help in pathology, I'll ask for it.
The constable suggested a drowning case.
Fished from the river, but he wasn't drowned.
By the look of those marks, an animal.
Exactly what I think, but what kind of animal leaves mutilations like those?
Chisel-like incisors. A rodent?
Yes, but that's impossible. Look at the size of them.
Hmm. Have you established the cause of death?
Yes, that's another curious thing. All this happened after death.
Really?
He was killed by a knife blow to the heart.
Are those his clothes?
Yes, sir. I'm just taking them for examination.
Hold that.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor swaps his cane for the clothes.

Dialogue.Line: He was carrying no personal documents, but this indicates he was a licensed cab driver.)

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Number 14305. Poor Buller.

Dialogue.Line: Easy enough to identify the poor chap by his number.
Doctor, those are the clothes the man we saw was wearing.
What I'd like to know is, what do you think of these?
Some sort of hair.
Yes. I think they're rat hairs.
Rat hairs? Do you know what you're saying, man?
Yes, of course I know what I'm saying.
But they're nearly three inches long. Hairs on a rat can't be more than what, quarter of an inch?
Interesting, isn't it, because I've just remembered something else about Weng-Chiang.
What?
He was the god of abundance. Yes, he made things grow. Can I borrow that?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He takes the Constable's lantern.

Dialogue.Line: Thank you.
Where are we going?
Stay there, Leela.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor leaves, and is followed by a Chinaman with a wicked looking axe.
The Chinaman throws the axe, which thuds into a doorframe next to the Doctor's head.

Dialogue.Line: Were you trying to attract my attention?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Chinaman falls to the ground. Leela walks up, clearing her blowpipe.

Dialogue.Line: What's this?
A Janis thorn.
Yes. I thought I told you not to carry
He was trying to kill you.
Oh. Oh, well, in that case you'd better come along.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Further along, they stop at a manhole cover.

Dialogue.Line: What is it?
The entrance to the sewers.
Blood. Is this where they took the body?
Yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor takes off his cape, pulls the cover aside and steps down.

Dialogue.Line: Where's it go?
Into the Thames eventually. All the sewers are connected.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Something massive is clawing at a grille across the sewer. The Doctor throws a flash-bang at it as they run back to the ladder.

Dialogue.Line: Out! Out!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor closes up the manhole again.

Dialogue.Line: We might have been killed!
It's ten feet from whiskers to tail.
We should have taken weapons.
What kind of weapons? You'd need a harpoon to stop that brute.
Shall we tell the blue guards?
They'd only call a Sanitary Inspector. It's a guard. It's there to keep people away.
What? Now where are we going?
Ah, it's black as Newgate's knocker down here. It's over this way, Mister Jago.
Flickering shadows, Casey. Trick of the light.
Shadows don't groan, Mister Jago. Shadows don't clank chains and moan like all the demented souls in hell.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The area under the stage is used to store props. Jago's lamp lights up a large painted face on a totem pole.

Dialogue.Line: There's your ghost. Six-gun Sadie and her Wild West troupe left that behind. All Lombard Street to ninepence, that's what you saw.
It weren't that old thing. Anyway, I heard it.
Ah, Casey, you're a pixilated leprechaun. The course of the river Fleet runs right under the foundations of this old theatre.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Which puts it several miles west of Limehouse, beyond the City and north of Temple.

Dialogue.Line: What you heard was a clang and the rush of water as they closed the sluice gates down on the Thames.
Ah, it's easy for you to cast aspersions, Mister Jago. You weren't down here.
Somebody else has been down here by the look of things. Have you got an admirer, Casey?
A glove, is it?
Yes, a lady's glove, monogrammed EB. Perhaps the ghost dropped it, eh? Come on, we've had enough of your spook.
No plan of the sewers?
We don't keep plans of sewers here, sir, but as far as I know, they all connect to the Fleet and then down to the river. But if you've got any information, sir?
At the moment, Sergeant, we're looking for information ourselves.
Professor Litefoot left a message for you, sir.
Did he?
It says he'd like to see you at the mortuary straight away.
It does.
He's still there, sir. We found another body outside after you'd gone.
What?
Another Chinese, sir, just outside.
Very convenient.
Very mysterious, sir. You wouldn't know anything about it, I suppose?
Of course we do. I was rescuing the Doctor
Come on, Leela!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Casey and Jago come out of Jago's office and go to the stage door.

Dialogue.Line: Go on home with you, Casey. Straight home. You might get mistaken for one of those girls.
Aren't you coming, Mister Jago?
Not yet. Some paperwork commands my presence yet awhile, but I shall doubtless descry those lugubrious liniments at the crepuscular hour.
Eh?
See you in the morning.
You're a card, Mister Jago. A card and a half.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Casey leaves the theatre. Chang comes up behind Jago, making him start.

Dialogue.Line: Jiminy, you made me jump. I thought you'd gone, Mister Chang.
No, Mister Jago, I have come back to see you.
See me, Mister Chang? Nothing wrong, I hope?
Be so kind as to step up to my dressing room, and I will explain.

If it's the terms of our contract, we've been attracting such good houses lately I've already considered drawing up a fresh agreement. The terms I have in mind as such I venture no other management in London would offer an artiste. What would you say to an extra two percent, Mister Chang? Of the gross, naturally. I think you'll agree that's fair.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jago falls silent as he gazes into Chang's mesmeric eyes.

Dialogue.Line: Now hear me, Jago. You remember the cab driver, Buller, who came to see me tonight?
Cab driver. Yes.
I want you to forget him, understand? You did not see him.
I did not see him.
Good. Now you will go from here to your office. When you sit down at your desk, you will remember only that you have just said goodnight to Casey. Is that clear?
I have just said goodnight to Casey.
Excellent. Now, go.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chang waves a hand in front of Jago, who harrumphs and leaves. Chang also leaves, and goes down to the cellar.

Chang lights a lamp and makes his way through the old props and costumes to a clear area of flagstoned floor. There he taps three times on one stone, which rises on a hinge to reveal a ladder going down into -
Chang kow-tows to a masked figure in a long cloak.

Dialogue.Line: You are late.
We should not go tonight, Lord.
I must, every night until the time cabinet is found.)

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He coughs and wheezes.

Dialogue.Line: You are ill.
I am dying, Chang. You must bring another linnet to my cage.
But only yesterday
The disease grows worse. Each distillation lasts less than the time before.
And with every girl reported missing, panic increases. I fear one of them will be traced here.
You must be careful.
Careful as I am, Lord, there is always risk of discovery. Even tonight I acted quickly to keep our secret. A man was on his way to police.
Bah. Those dumb-witted oxen. Chang, I have given you mental powers undreamt of in this century. You are thousands of years ahead of your time. What can you fear from these primitives?
True, Lord, I read their minds with ease, but tonight there was a stranger, a man whose thoughts were hidden. A man different from all others.
Describe him.
He is a doctor. Tall with wide pale eyes and hair that curls like the ram. He ask many questions.
A time agent would not ask questions. A time agent would know.
But I fear danger, Lord, and have sent a man to kill him.
Your opium-addicted scum are all bunglers, Chang. You should have seen to it yourself.
If he troubles us further, Lord, I will deal with him personally.
Very well. We're wasting time. Come.
I've taken some of the organs for further tests, but I must confess to being beaten.
Beaten?
They were both poisoned, of course. One orally, the other intravenously. I understand you suggested scorpion venom?
Yes, in concentrated form.
I'd like to hear more about that. You're in this line, I take it?
I've dabbled a bit. Dilettante.
Surely more than that. I got a zoologist colleague to look at our last cadaver. It seems he thinks it's the work of a rat, too. What an amazing night it's been.
It is not over yet.

It's been jolly interesting, wouldn't you say? Most of the corpses around here are jolly dull. Now I've got a couple of inscrutable Chinks and a poor perisher who was chewed by a giant rat, having been stabbed by a midget.
A midget?
Angle of the wound. Oh, upon my soul. I'm sure we shouldn't be discussing such things in front of the fair sex. Forgive us, ma'am.
What for?
For being so indelicate in the presence of a lady of refinement.
Does he mean me?
I don't think so.
It's very interesting. You say you can tell the height of the attacker by the way the blade was thrust? But when aiming for the heart, we were always taught to strike under the breastbone.
Upon my soul!
Savage. Found floating down the Amazon in a hat box.
A hat box?
Professor, still here? I've traced our cab driver. Name of Joseph Buller, 14 Fish Lane, this parish.
Oh, splendid. You can let the coroner have all the details, then. Is there someone to identify the clothing?
His mother in law, Mrs Nellie Gusset. Same address. Deceased has lived there since his marriage six month ago.
Anything else?
Sir?
Well, you had a few drinks with Mrs Gusset. Did she tell you anything further about the deceased?
A bearer of sad tidings, sir. I shared a glass or two while the poor thing got over the shock. Yes, well, she did mention the deceased had been in a queer state all day.
Why?

Well, it seems his wife, that's Emma Buller, daughter of the house, didn't come home last night. Deceased refused to take his cab out today as a consequence. Deceased then had several drinks and went round the Palace Theatre.
The theatre?
Oh, not on pleasure bent, sir. It seems he believed that's where his wife was to be found. Mrs Gusset says he went off making horrible asseverations as to his intentions.
Yes, well, er, put as much in that report as you think will concern the coroner, officer. It's quite clear the man got stupidly drunk and picked a fight with a dwarf.
Yes, sir.
A night's work like that always does wonders for my appetite. I'd be honoured if you'd share some supper with me.
I'd be delighted, Professor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Leela watches, fascinated, as Litefoot light up his pipe.

Dialogue.Line: Of course, the police will have the Buller case cleared up in no time, but the Chinese, different kettle of fish, what?
Why are you making fire in your mouth?
Why am I? Upon my sam. Hasn't the girl seen a pipe before?
There's no tobacco where Leela comes from.
Sounds healthy, but exceedingly dull. Yes, as I was saying, they're a mysterious lot, the Chinese. Enigmatic. I never got anywhere near to understanding them, and I was brought up in China.
Really? What were you doing there?

My father was Brigadier General in the punitive expedition of 1860\. Afterwards he stayed in Peking as a palace attaché. Died there in the end, poor old buffer. Fireworks at the funeral. Odd custom. Odd sort of people.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor raps on the hood of the cab.

Dialogue.Line: What's up?
They use fireworks to frighten off evil spirits.
I know that. Where are you going?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor gets out of the cab.

Dialogue.Line: You stay with Litefoot. I'll join you later. Drive on, cabbie.
Where are you going?
Palace theatre.
There'll be nobody there at this hour!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The cab drives on.

Dialogue.Line: Extraordinary. I say, how can he join us later? I haven't given him m'card.
Four Ranskill Gardens. He heard you tell the driver.
Gad, he's as sharp as a trout.
Trout?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Someone is knocking at the stage door.

Dialogue.Line: All right. Coming!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jago opens the door to the Doctor, who barges straight past him.

Dialogue.Line: Yes?
Terrible weather for the time of the year.
The theatre's closed.
Shush.
What do you want?
Are you the manager?
I'm the owner, sir. Henry Gordon Jago at the end of a long day, so if you'd kindly state your business.
Henry Gordon Jago, how do you do, sir. I'm the Doctor.
Doctor?
Exactly.
Ah, now I've rumbled your game. I admire your brass, but it won't do. Call back on Saturday.
Don't move. Hold that.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jago takes the Doctor's cane. The Doctor pulls a string of coloured handkerchiefs from Jago's top pocket.

Dialogue.Line: Auditions commence at ten o'clock sharp. Supporting acts booked for one week only.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor puts a lid over a metal pan and removed it to reveal a white dove.

Dialogue.Line: Is that all?
No. Dramatic recitations, singing, tap-dancing. I can play the Trumpet Voluntary in a bowl of live goldfish.
Don't bother coming back on Saturday.
I'm also a master hypnotist. Now then.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor swings Jago's pocket watch in front of his eyes.

Dialogue.Line: How long since you were under the influence, sir?
I'm a man of character and determination, sir. The Rock of Gibraltar would be more easily, more easily.
Just as I thought, and quite recently, too. What was your last order?
To remember nothing since I said goodnight to Casey.
Henry Gordon Jago, I command you to remember everything you were ordered to forget. When I count to three, you will remember everything. One, two, three.
More easily influenced than I would. I have a will of iron. What the Dickens am I talking about?
Did a cab driver come here tonight?
Yes, there was a fellow burst in and accosted Mister Chang between shows.
What did he want?
Something about his Emma. Lady friends, no doubt.
Emma Buller, his wife. She disappeared last night. Does Mister Chang by any chance do a vanishing lady act?
You're not by any chance suggesting that Mister Chang has anything to do with these missing
What is it?
Emma Buller.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jago takes the monogrammed glove from his pocket and gives it to the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: EB. Where did you find this?
In the cellar. Are you from the police?
I'm helping them. I'd like to see this cellar, Mister Jago.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Weng, Chang and Sin are travelling down a nice middle-class residential street. Weng holds a fat circular object.

Dialogue.Line: You are certain these are different streets?
The driver has his orders. Every night we quarter a new sector.
For how much longer?
Patience, Lord. We know the time cabinet is here. The cabinet of Weng- Chiang in the house of an infidel. We shall recover it.
I grow weary, Chang.
Tomorrow I bring you two donors. Young, plump, high-spirited girls. The distillation of their life essences will recover your powers, Lord.
It was over here. Here, this is where it was, down here.
What were you doing down here?
I was reassuring Casey
Who?

My factotum. He's taken to seeing ghosts lately. He's a good fellow, Casey, but about as sharp as the corners of a round table. Great Jumping Jehosophat! What a spider! That must be the granddaddy of them all.
It's a money spider.
A money spider?
Yes.
Don't kill it.
Genetic disruption. Where does it come from? What's under here?
You mean right where we're standing?
Yes.
Well, they say the course of the River Fleet runs right
Fleet?
Yes, the River Fleet runs right under these foundations.
Excellent. We're getting somewhere.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Litefoot lights a gas lamp.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, now, let's see what we have here. Mrs Hudson always leaves me a cold collation.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The sideboard is covered in dishes.

Dialogue.Line: Ham, roast beef, chicken, tongue. Those look like quail, unless I'm much mistaken.
Meat.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Leela grabs a large joint of ribs and bites into it.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, well, perhaps we shouldn't wait for your friend the Doctor. Help yourself, my dear. Plates on the end of the table. I'll, er, I'll just put a log or two on the fire.
It's good.
Oh, I'm so glad.
Is something wrong?
No, no. Would you care for a knife or a fork?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Leela picks up a large carving knife and uses it on the joint.

Dialogue.Line: It's a good knife. Aren't you going to eat?
Yes, yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He picks up a plate, decides not to embarrass Leela and picks up a leg of lamb with his hands.

Dialogue.Line: Just going to eat.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Weng's device starts glowing.

Dialogue.Line: Stop! Stop! Somewhere here. Somewhere! One of these dwellings!)

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They all get out of the cab, and follow a path indicated by the glowing, pulsing disc.

Dialogue.Line: This is the place, Chang. The time cabinet is in there.
Leave the rest to your servants, Lord. Go back to your abode.
I must have the time (cough) cabinet.
Lord, your weakness grows. Go, go back. Rest. I will bring the cabinet to you.
Very well, but do not fail me now, Chang.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor throws another prop aside.

Dialogue.Line: Well, if there is a secret entrance, it's expertly hidden.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: An apparition of something covered in a white sheet appears, clanking some chains.

Dialogue.Line: How very interesting.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jago faints.

Dialogue.Line: Do you know what this is? Oh, come on, Rock of Gibraltar.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor drags Jago away.

Dialogue.Character: (They are now seated at the table, eating from plates, although Leela doesn't appear to have used her knife and fork. She picks up a large bowl of a dessert to drink, then looks to wipe her hands on the table cloth. That's a step too far. LITEFOOT
Dialogue.Line: Napkin. LEELA: Thank you, Professor. LITEFOOT: The Doctor's taking a long time. I hope he did note the address.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Litefoot returns his sherry glass to the drinks table and looks out through the curtains of the bay window.

Dialogue.Line: Great Scott!
What is it?
There's somebody out there watching the house.
Where?
Someone stepped back into the shrubbery as I looked out.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Litefoot takes a revolver from a drawer.

Dialogue.Line: Some scoundrel up to no good. Odd thing. I could swear he was a Chinese. Well, whoever he is, I'll give him more than he expected. No, you wait here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jago wakes up.

Dialogue.Line: How are you feeling?
The ghost! I saw it. Casey, forgive me.
No.
I saw it.
It was a hologram.
I always thought there was something unnatural about that cellar.
There's nothing unnatural about the holograph technique. Projection of light by a laser beam.
What?
Don't worry. It wasn't known in this century.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor takes a small flask from his cane.

Dialogue.Line: Drink this. Go on, you'll feel better.
What's that?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A light in the main theatre.

Dialogue.Line: Shush.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor goes to investigate. From the main stage he sees a light up in the roof, so he starts to climb a backstage ladder up to the scenery rigs. Something throws a papier mache head down at him, and he falls back into a costume hamper. He starts to climb again, and we see that the person he is pursuing ever higher is Weng. The masked phantom of the music hall takes hold of one of the ropes and swings across the width of the stage. The Doctor runs to the middle of a gantry but has lost sight of him. Then he is pushed off from behind, and only manages to save himself by grabbing onto a scenery backdrop. Weng slides down a rope to the ground. Jago enters the stage to investigate the noises and gets hit over the head as Weng makes for the cellar. Finally the piece of scenery tears, dropping the Doctor fairly gently to the stage.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, oh Doctor.
Cheer up, Jago, cheer up.
He's gone back to his rats. Are you all right.
Yes, I think so. Who the devil was it?
I've no idea. He didn't introduce himself.
Shall I call in the local police?
Oh, Henry Gordon Jago. Then our reclusive phantom would simply vanish, poof!
Oh, good heavens, yes.
We can tackle it together, you and I.
What are you going to do?
Think. I'm going to have some supper.
Ah.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Inside, Leela picks up a knife from the dining table and throws it into Mister Sin's throat. The 'dummy' continues to totter forward and she backs away. Out in the entrance hall, Chang takes Litefoot's revolver then hears the Doctor walking up the road whistling 'Colonel Bogey'. He leaves the house and hides behind a privet hedge. Inside, Leela gets away from Mister Sin by jumping onto the table then leaping through the window. Outside, the Doctor hears the noise and ducks just as Chang fires the revolver at him. He runs for the house, avoiding the second shot.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor.
Shush.
Doctor.
Shush.
Doctor.
Sin!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sin turns and totters out of the dining room.

Dialogue.Line: Where's Litefoot?
He went out. He said he'd seen a Chinaman outside the window.
And you jumped through it.
Something like that.
Stay here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chang carries a limp Sin down the front steps as the Doctor goes round the back of the house and gets inside by standing on a barrel to get through a small open window. Leela watches Chang and Sin get into a hansom cab that pulls up outside, then runs and jumps on the back as it drives away. The Doctor comes out of the front door.

Dialogue.Line: Leela! Leela, no! Don't! Leela.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Professor is awake and sitting at the table. The Doctor shouts to someone outside the room.

Dialogue.Line: Ice!
The sheer criminal effrontery. Things are coming to a pretty pass when ruffians will attack a man in his own home.)

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor puts a bunch of icecubes tied in a napkin on Litefoot's head.

Dialogue.Line: Well, they were Chinese ruffians.
I wonder what they intended?
Robbery?
Well, there are some pretty valuable things here. That K'ang-hsi vase, for instance. My family brought that back from Peking. Or that Chinese puzzle box.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The 'box' is a massive cabinet taller than the Doctor, with a large circular strongroom style dial on the front.

Dialogue.Line: It doesn't open. Chap spent a week here once looking for a secret spring.
Fused molecules.
No, no, no, no. Lacquered bronze.
It's extraordinary. It's from this planet.
A parting gift from the Emperor.
Technology this advanced? Ah! Got it! Well, of course, that's the answer.
What the Dickens are you raving about, Doctor?
Weng-Chiang.
Weng-Chiang?
Weng-Chiang. I do hope that girl Leela isn't in danger.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: That girl Leela has followed Chang to the theatre cellar, where he raps on the flagstone and goes down into Weng's laboratory.

Dialogue.Line: You will explain yourself, Li H'sen.
I will not tolerate failure!
There has been no failure, Lord.
Then where is the time cabinet?
The house is marked. When night returns, my brothers in the band of death will strike.
I put no trust in your dockyard riff-raff.
Lord, for your glory they would die willingly.
Opium sodden scum. Strike!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chang sounds the brass gong and Weng pulls a rope that lifts a cover to reveal a six foot across round sewer entrance, with a large grill.

Dialogue.Line: Lord, I promise you will have the great cabinet of Weng-Chiang before another dawn.
I had better. I grow weary of this hole in the ground.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Weng throws a large chunk of meat through the grill.

Dialogue.Line: You are safe here, Lord.
Safe? It is a trap, and I was seen returning to it.
Tonight?
Yes, and now he knows where I am, he will be back.
Who?
By your description, the one you have already failed to kill.
The Doctor! I knew he was a danger.
Listen, Li H'sen.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The giant rat takes the meat.

Dialogue.Line: The beasts of darkness. I have made them larger and more savage than lions! Yes, yes, the Doctor is a danger, and he was brought to my door by your blundering. You see what it means, Li H'sen?
He will die.
The list of your failures is growing. I must be ready to move quickly. I need strength.
I will bring a girl, Lord.
One will not be enough this time. I need two fresh young donors, and I need them at once.
It is not easy at this hour, Lord.
No excuses! Get them!
Yes, Lord.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Leela follows Chang out of the cellar.
The Doctor is drawing a map of the Thames on the tablecloth. Litefoot enters.

Dialogue.Line: Haven't you slept?
Sleep is for tortoises.
Any news of Miss Leela?
Not yet.
Perhaps we should inform the police?
No, there are already nine missing girls on their list.
Oh yes, but surely missing under very different circumstances.
No. If my suspicions are correct, then I know what those poor girls were used for, and I can't imagine a more grisly fate. He's a blackguard.
Who's a blackguard?

I don't know who's a blackguard. Some slavering gangrenous vampire comes out of a sewer and stalks this city at night, he's a blackguard. I've got to find his lair and I haven't got an hour to loose. Look. You see? I've been trying to trace the line of the sewers. That's the Thames, this is the line of the Fleet, and that is the Palace Theatre.
I'm beginning to see what you're getting at.
Good. Good.
Yes, well, er, if you've finished with the tablecloth, I think I'd better dispose of that before my housekeeper arrives.
Right.
How'd you know the course of the Fleet? It's been covered for centuries.
I caught a salmon there once. Would have hung over the sides of this table. Shared it with the Venerable Bede. He adored fish.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Litefoot gathers up the tablecloth and puts it into a wicker hamper in the entrance hall.

Dialogue.Line: Professor, you don't happen to have an elephant gun, do you?
Elephants? Why on Earth do you want an elephant gun?
We're about to embark on a very dangerous mission.
Well, I've a Chinese fowling piece if that's any good. Used for duck, mainly.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor looks at the long-barreled weapon.

Dialogue.Line: Made in Birmingham. Yes, that's the main requirement. Could you get me a small boat?
I imagine so. May I ask the purpose of these preparations?
Yes. To find the confluence of the Thames and Fleet, Professor, then to follow the Fleet.
And then?
Oh, and then we shall see.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Leela sneaks along behind a wall as a cab pulls up outside a house and a woman gets out. She pays off the driver.

Dialogue.Line: Ta, ducks.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The cab drives off. Chang sneaks up behind the working woman.

Dialogue.Line: Oh!
Pleasant are the dreams of morning.
You gave me a turn, dearie.
Fresh as dew and bright with promise.
Yeah, well, that's how you might see it, Mister Ching-ching, but as far as I'm concerned all I want is a pair of smoked kippers, a cup of rosie and put me plates up for a few hours, savvy?
Budding lotus of the dawn, despicable Chang has other ideas.
Well, I can tell you what to do with your ideas.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She looks into his mesmeric eyes.

Dialogue.Line: You will come with me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Leela watches Chang lead the woman away, then follows.
Chang sits Teresa in his chair.

Dialogue.Line: Await my return.

Dialogue.Character: (Leela hides as Chang comes down the stairs from his dressing room. Someone laughs nearby, and Chang goes towards the sound. Two men are sitting in the theatre, laughing as a young woman sweeps the floor down in front of the stage. Leela enters the dressing room. LEELA
Dialogue.Line: The spell of the shaman.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Something sniggers nearby. Leela opens a wardrobe. Downstairs, Chang hypnotises the cleaning girl and leads her upstairs. He speaks to the woman sitting in the chair.

Dialogue.Line: Come. I said come!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: We see that Teresa has been undressed and put into the wardrobe.
Chang drags both women by the hand.

Dialogue.Line: Come, you painted drabs. My master must feed.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A boatman is rowing the Doctor and Litefoot past a moored ship at St Katherine's Dock, by the Tower of London.

Dialogue.Line: There it is, fifty yards ahead.
Sit down, Doctor. The man knows these waters.
I've always enjoyed messing about in boats.
I think this entire enterprise is extremely rash and ill-considered.
My dear Litefoot, I've got a lantern and a pair of waders, and possibly the most fearsome piece of hand artillery in all England. What could possibly go wrong?
Well, that for a start. It hasn't been fired for fifty years. If you try to use it, it'll probably explode in your face.
Explode? Unthinkable. It was made in Birmingham. Tie up over there, skipper.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The boatman brings them to a grill in the embankment. This is not really where the Fleet meets the Thames, but never mind, it'll do for the story.
The cleaning girl is in her underwear. The 'whore' is still fully dressed.

Dialogue.Line: You will hear the commands of my master, Weng-Chiang, and obey.
Where did you get them?
Are they unsuitable, Lord?
They're not the best, but they'll do. They're young. Their life essence is still strong. Oh, this one has muscles like a horse!
I took what I could find, Lord.
I have given you knowledge. I have made you a leader among your fellows. All I have asked for in return is a few contemptible slatterns who will never be missed.
But they are missed, Lord. And because your need is so great, I've been forced to move unwisely.
Unwisely?
I took this one from the rooms above. Nobody saw, but it will bring the police even nearer.
It is of no consequence. Once I have the time cabinet, I can move from here. Now put this one in the distillation chamber.
Yes, Lord.
Leave me to my work. (to Leela) I shall not keep you waiting long.
All right, Doctor?
All right, Professor.
I'll wait for you for two hours, then.
Yes, no more. If I'm still in here at high tide.
Yes?
Don't bother.
Oh. Well, good luck!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Leela is now down to her ample Victorian underwear. Weng pulls levers on his contraption and the device the cleaning girl is standing in starts to hum. The air around her shimmers then goes opaque. Leela throws a scarf over Weng's head and kicks him down. She reverses the controls but the girl is dead, her skin darkened and desiccated. Leela makes for the ladder, and Weng fires a ray gun at her. He misses as she jumps down and hides behind a bench full of testtubes and glass retorts. He starts to crawl round it and she runs for the open grill to the sewers and climbs through before he can stagger there. Weng sounds the gong.

Dialogue.Line: When my beauties find her, she will wish she had died here!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He closes the cover to the sewers. The giant rats screech as Leela runs off. The Doctor hears them and keeps walking. Meanwhile, two coolies run up to Litefoot's house with a handcart bearing wicker baskets labelled Limehouse Laundry. They carry one into the house and remove the one that Litefoot put the tablecloth into, then take it away. On the river, a peal of Westminster chimes can be heard. Litefoot checks his watch. The water is still well below the level of grill.
The working woman has woken from her hypnosis and come down the stairs.

Dialogue.Line: Hey, you. What's your business here?
Business? Where the devil am I?
Oh, you wouldn't be knowing.
What happened to me last night? Can't remember a thing.
Look, if there's anything missing, I'll remember you sure enough. Now you come on, get on out of here.
Get your hands off of me! I'm a lady.
What's the trouble, Casey?
No trouble, Mister Jago. I'm just seeing this lady off the premises.
Oh, my lord. It was him! It was him!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She points to a poster of Chang on the wall.

Dialogue.Line: Mister Chang? What are you talking about?
Quick, let me out of this place! Let me go!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She runs out of the stage door.

Dialogue.Line: Another case of the screaming oopizootics. I'll bear that in mind.
What?
It might have some relevance to the matter in hand.
What matter?

The investigation, Casey. These missing females. I've made the acquaintance of a very high-up gentleman, an amateur investigator who's been called in personally by the Yard. Scotland Yard. And I am assisting him.
No.
I am. He told me to watch, Casey, and I am watching, everywhere.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chang has overheard this conversation.
Leela and the Doctor are still trying to avoid the giant rat in the sewers.

Dialogue.Line: You incompetent fool! She was a tigress!
She substituted herself for the woman I had found. The police must be closing in.
My rats will dispose of her, but you, Li H'sen, have made too many mistakes.
That girl. She was with the doctor. It is not the police, it is he who sent her.
Vacant excuses. You have failed me! You know that until I have the time cabinet, I can never be whole again, never escape from this hideous condition. Yet knowing this, you still failed me.
Lord, hear me. I would lay down my life in your service.
You are dismissed, Li H'sen. I can no longer leave my fate in your blundering hands.
Great one, let me find this doctor. Let me strike him down for the harm he has done you.
Do not beg. You have proved unworthy. Go!
I await your commands, Lord.
Go!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chang leaves. Weng turns on his contraption and the shimmering effect enters his body.
The Doctor fires the old fowling piece. There is lots of smoke, then silence. When the smoke clears, the giant rat lies dead in the water, partly on top of Leela.

Dialogue.Line: Leela? Leela, are you all right?
Oh, thank you, Doctor. Yes, I'm all right, just bruised.
You were lucky.
I deserve death. I had the chance to kill our enemy, Doctor, and I failed.
Which enemy?
The yellow one calls him lord. He lives in a cave beneath the theatre. Come, I will show you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Another giant rat calls in the darkness.

Dialogue.Line: This gun takes about half an hour to load. Let's go this way.
Casey, I'm about to repair for half a foot of port. Mrs Samuelson in yet?
I've not seen her, Mister Jago.
Well, you tell her I want the girl's frillies smartening up. They looked like a fit-up company last night. One of them had a Jacob's ladder as long as my arm. Look at that. You tell her.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jago hands the black stocking to Casey.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, Mister Jago.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jago opens the stage door to reveal Chang.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, Mister Chang. Back again already? I shall have to start charging you rent, what?
There are many things to prepare before the performance.
Of course, Mister Chang. Yes. The art that conceals, eh? Tell me, last night.
Last night?
I'm working too hard. Too much in the old brain box, that's a fact, but, er. We talked about a new contract but I've quite forgotten how we left matters.
I'm considering your new offer.
Ah, I see. Splendid. Generous offer?
Merely reasonable. Tonight, incidentally, I shall be appearing without Mister Sin.
Oh, why is that? Just making a change?
Mister Sin is indisposed.
Ha, ha, very droll. I shall treasure that exceedingly humorous jest, Mister Chang. Oh, Mister Chang? I suppose the little fellow's got a touch of woodworm, what?
Say that again?
Hmm?
Say that again.
She was dead. Her skin was dry like old leaves. It was something the machine did to her.
Like old leaves. Sounds like an organic distillation. Drained out the life essence.
That's what he called it.
Did he?
Well, he seemed to know what he was talking about.
Well, he doesn't. He's a madman.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Litefoot enters with parcels.

Dialogue.Line: Here we are. Your outfit, my dear.
Oh, thank you, Professor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Leela takes off the blanket and puts down the cup of hot whatever and goes to open them.

Dialogue.Line: No, no, not here. Mrs Hudson's waiting upstairs. She'll help you change. Hope it's suitable.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Leela picks up the parcels and leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Dashed embarrassing business, eh? Never done it before.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is examining the Chinese cabinet.

Dialogue.Line: What?
Chosen togs for a girl.
Ah.
Quite apart from the rum things they wear, you have to be jolly careful it's in the right fashion. Clothes matter to women.
They do?
Still trying to open it, are you?
Yes. I'm trying to place the period. It can only be opened by a key of the correct molecular combination.
Is that a fact?
Yes.
What were you saying when I came in? Something about a madman?
Yes, he's probably got the key.
Who?
Well, presumably he's calling himself Weng-Chiang.
Weng-Chiang was one of the ancient Chinese gods.
I know that, Professor, I know. And he probably arrived in this contraption.
It was a gift to Mama from his highness, T'ung-Chi. We came home in seventy three, so it's been in the family quite some years now.
Then you're very lucky, Professor, that he hasn't traced it before now.
Weng-Chiang?
Weng

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Leela enters, in a green chevroned dress with mutton-chop sleeves and her hair done up. She looks delighted with herself.

Dialogue.Line: Do you like it?
Yes, it's charming. Isn't it charming, Professor?
Quite delightful.
I'll be proud to take to take you to the theatre looking like that.
We're going to the theatre?
I have an appointment at the Palace Theatre tonight, and if you're very good, I'll buy you an orange.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: We look down on the two men walking along the stage behind the curtains.

Dialogue.Line: Told her.
What?
Mrs Samuelson. I told her what you said.
Oh.
She didn't like it.
I don't need to hear that, Casey. I'm not concerned with what Mrs Samuelson likes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They walk past racks of costumes lining a corridor.

Dialogue.Line: She mentioned money matters. She wants a word with you.
The woman's a bloodsucker. She's trying to ruin me.
Well she said

Don't tell me, Casey. I'm an artiste. Every night at this time, I feel like an old warhorse scenting the smoke of the battlefield. As the house fills, the blood starts tingling through my veins. My public is out there waiting for me. I can't talk about money at a time like this.
But you don't do anything, Mister Jago.

I, I announce the acts, I count the tickets, I smile at people. You've no idea of the strain it puts on a fellow. Furthermore, she spend seventeen and threepence on the wardrobe last week. Any sign of the Doctor yet?
Who?
My collaborator and fellow sleuth. Oh well, he'll be here tonight keeping observation, Casey.
I'll lay a guinea to a gooseberry on it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chang enters his dressing room, having overheard Jago. He goes to his dressing table, takes a revolver out of a drawer, and loads it.
The Doctor and Leela are playing draughts. She is sitting cross-legged on the table and wearing a hat.

Dialogue.Line: Your cab's here.
Good.
You'll need your coats. It's getting thick again.
Hmm. Did you pass word to the police?
Oh, yes, yes. They've posted a man outside.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor takes Leela's three remaining draughts.

Dialogue.Line: Good. Lock and bolt the door after us and keep your gun handy. Come on.
What, you really think those scoundrels will come back?
They might. They might. They'll do anything to get their hands on that cabinet.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Where the Chinese laundry hamper sits hidden in plain view.

Dialogue.Line: Don't you worry, Doctor. By shots, I'll be ready for them. They won't catch George Litefoot napping a second time.
Palace Theatre, cabbie. Make it snappy.
Go on, get up.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The cab drives off past the policeman on guard at the gate.
Weng is packing pieces of equipment into a large carpet bag when there is a knocking on the trap door. He pulls the chain to open it then calls up the ladder.

Dialogue.Line: What is it?
Your servant, master.
Go away. I have work to attend to.
Lord, I have heard that the strange infidel, the Doctor, will be here soon. Is it still your wish that I should kill him?
I think it more likely that he will kill you.
No, Lord. I have plan. I will kill him as sacrifice to appease the wrath of my god Weng-Chiang, to prove that I above all others am your true servant.
You no longer serve me, Li H'sen. I shall take my own measures. You do what you will. Now go!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The orchestra is tuning up.

Dialogue.Line: You owe me a gooseberry, Casey. There he is, in the box. See?
He don't look like a detective to me.
Well, he's not going to wear a brown derby and boots, is he, secret investigator like him, a man of a thousand faces.
Who's the girl?
Window dressing. Part of his disguise. Tell you what, I think I'll just pop up and tell him we're all on the q v down here. Have you set the star trap yet?
Not yet, Mister Jago.
You'd better get on with it, hadn't you, unless you want to ruin Mister Chang's act for him.
It's that cellar, Mister Jago.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Leela is looking at the brightly coloured programme when Jago creeps in behind them. She turns, but the Doctor does not.

Dialogue.Line: Psst.
Good evening, Mister Jago.
Pleasure to welcome you, sir, and your charming companion.
Thank you. Are you quite comfortable down there?
Oh, I know the value of discretion in matters like this, Doctor. May I ask if you've come to any further deductions?
Oh, quite a few, quite a few.
Ah. I thought as much when I saw you here. I take it you're on the point of solving the mystery of the missing girls.
I'm expecting further developments very soon, Mister Jago.
Ah. Well, if you need any help, Doctor, I hope I know where my duty lies.
I knew I could rely on you.
Oh, to the limit, though I suppose you've got your own men scattered throughout the audience.
No.
No? You mean nobody?
Nobody. When the moment comes, Mister Jago, you and I can face our destiny shoulder to shoulder.
Oh, corks.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Back at the house, Litefoot is reading Blackwood's Edinburgh Magazine no 1916, with an advert for Lee and Perrins Worcestershire sauce on the back, by the light of the fire. He puts it down and looks out of the window to see the policeman patrolling in the garden then returns to continue reading. Meanwhile, Lettie Randall is singing on stage.

Dialogue.Line: Daisy, Daisy, give me your answer, do. I'm half crazy all for the love of you. It won't be a stylish marriage. I can't afford a carriage. But you'll look sweet on the seat of a bicycle build for two. Everybody now!
Daisy, Daisy.
Do we need to give the responses?
There's no obligation.
I'm half crazy
When shall we go and look for the cave creature?
Perhaps it'll come looking for us.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Under the stage, Weng climbs the ladder out of his laboratory as Casey prepares the trap door as instructed. Then he turns and sees the masked horror.

Dialogue.Line: No. No!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jago does his Master of Ceremonies piece after Lettie's turn.

Dialogue.Line: The Sheffield song thrush. Last time she was here, there were eggs all over the stage. Now, ladies and gentlemen, it is my great privilege to introduce to you, in his extended season here at the Palace, the first of two appearances this evening, someone whose legendary legerdemain has entranced and entertained all the crowned heads of Europe. Here to baffle and bewilder in his eclectic extravaganza of efflorescent ectoplasm, that master magician from the Orient, Li H'sen Chang!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Drum roll, flash-bang, and Chang appears from the trap door, presumably. His assistant runs on with a covered table.

Dialogue.Line: First trick very simple.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He throws his cape to the side of the stage, where there is another flash- bang and shower of glitter.

Dialogue.Line: Next trick very simple.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: His assistant hands him a deck of cards.

Dialogue.Line: Will someone pick cards, please? You sir. Catchee.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chang throws the pack he has just shuffled up to the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: Now, sir, please to assist humble Chang by selecting any card. Ace of diamonds. Please to hold card in air so everyone see. Now, sir, please to return card to pack, any place. Honourable gentleman please to hold pack of playing cards between finger and thumb. Chang will now shoot magic bullet through ace of diamonds without hitting other cards. Please to keep very still.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chang aims the revolver.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor slowly brings the pack of cards towards his face. The audience gasps.

Dialogue.Line: Please to keep very quiet. Chang shoot fifteen peasants learning this trick.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chang fires. There is no apparent bullet hole anywhere.

Dialogue.Line: Now, sir, please look for ace of diamonds.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor holds up a card with a hole where the single diamond should be. Applause.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, very good, very good! Wasn't that good? Anything else?
Honourable gentleman please to bring cards to stage. I have further demonstration requiring nerves of steel.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor goes down to the stage as a man-sized cabinet is wheeled on. Back at Litefoot's house, two Chinese men creep up behind the policeman and throw an axe into his back. Inside, the lid of the laundry basket rises to reveal Mister Sin. Litefoot has fallen asleep in his chair.

Dialogue.Line: I will now ask my eager volunteer kindly to step into the Cabinet of Death.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor has to bend his knees to fit. Chang shuts the doors, turns the cabinet, and the Doctor walks out and off the stage in full view of the audience, who laugh. Chang has not noticed, and turns the cabinet back to the front of the stage then opens it.

Dialogue.Line: The bird has flown. One of us is yellow.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chang's assistant gets into the cabinet.

Dialogue.Line: If you will now pay close attention, ladies and gentlemen.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chang takes a sword, hits the cabinet with it then thrusts it through the middle. Then a second one.
The assistant climbs down a ladder from a stage trap door and is confronted by Weng. He cowers on the floor.

Dialogue.Line: So, the great magician.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chang prepares to put the ninth sword through the cabinet.

Dialogue.Line: In my country, this is known as the death of a thousand cuts.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor hands Chang the tenth sword with a large grin. The cabinet is turned right round and the swords quickly pulled out.

Dialogue.Line: I will now ask my new volunteer kindly to assist in opening cabinet.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Casey falls out, dead.

Dialogue.Line: The curtain! Quick, drop the curtain! What happened?
He's dead. He died of a fright.
Poor Casey. He's worked here for years.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chang sneaks away as Leela and the stagehands gather round.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, what happened? Did Chang kill him?
No, Chang was as surprised as anyone. Where's he gone?
Are you here, Master? This is your servant, Li H'sen.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chang lights a lamp and looks around.

Dialogue.Line: Answer me, Lord. If you're here, answer me. He has gone. Weng-Chiang, lord of greatness, has deserted me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Someone enters.

Dialogue.Line: Lord?
You've been left to carry the can, Chang.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chang fiddles with his ring, but the Doctor knocks the pill from his hands.

Dialogue.Line: No poison tonight. There are questions to answer.
I will say nothing. It is time for me to join my forefathers.
Well, as an accomplice to murder, the police shouldn't hold you up long. Tell me about Weng-Chiang. Where did he go?
Perhaps back to his great palace in the sky. I failed him. He was displeased with me.
His mind is broken.
Li H'sen, you know he's not a god, don't you.
He came like a god. He appeared in a blazing cabinet of fire. I saw him and helped him. He was tired from his journey.
Go on.
He was ill for many months. I was but a humble peasant, but I gave him sanctuary while the soldiers searched. I nursed him.
The cabinet. What happened to the cabinet?
Soldiers of T'ung-Chi took it. Ever since, we have searched for the great cabinet of Weng-Chiang. The god will not be made whole until it is recovered.
Doctor, are you down here? Well, cover me in creosote. I never knew this was here.
Doctor!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chang has sneaked over to the big grill into the sewers. He goes through and the cover comes down.

Dialogue.Line: Not this time, Leela.
But he's escaping!
There's no escape that way. He's gone to join his ancestors.
You mean to say the celestial Chang was involved in all these Machiavellian machinations?
Yes, up to his epicanthic eyebrows.
Well, I'll go to Australia.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Screams from the sewers.

Dialogue.Line: What in the name of heaven's that?
You'll have to book yourself a new act tomorrow. Cyanide gas might do for the brutes, though you'd have to shut the sewers off for a day or two.
Look at this, Doctor. This is all that's left of them.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A small wardrobe of women's clothes.

Dialogue.Line: Of the missing girls? So it was Chang.
Not Chang. His master, the crazed maniac who organised all this.
Doctor! The machine's gone.
That means he's going to start up all over again somewhere else.
He could be anywhere. We'll have to look for him.
With his DNA helixes split open, the more cells he absorbs into himself, the more deformed he becomes.
You mean he is like a waterbag with a hole in the bottom, and the hole is getting bigger?
Yes.
What happened to make him like that?
Perhaps because he used the cabinet. A dangerous experiment in time travel. Now he'll be struggling to keep his metabolism in balance.
And the rats?
Just an experiment. He had to gauge the strength of the psionic amplification field. The rats were handy. After that, they were useful as sewer guards.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Leela leave.

Dialogue.Line: I've got it! See the lair of the phantom. Conducted tours, bob a nob. I'm on to a fortune here. Hey, Doctor, you're not going, are you?
I must. Things to do. (sotto) We've got to get back to that time cabinet. Come on. (A screech from a giant rat in the sewer drives Jago up the ladder.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Leela find the policeman's body.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor pulls the axe from the body.

Dialogue.Line: Litefoot's got visitors.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor notices the open laundry hamper in the hallway. Litefoot has just wakened when he burst in.

Dialogue.Line: Mi how ma! What happened?
Chinese. Dozens of them.
What?
Oh, the devils.
Well, they got what they came for.
What?
The time cabinet.
Damn scoundrels.
Get him a drink.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Leela sniffs the contents of the decanter.

Dialogue.Line: In a glass. In a glass. Professor, how did they get in?
I've, I've no idea. I locked and bolted all the doors as soon as you left. Thank you, my dear.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor goes into the hallway and tears a label off a rack.

Dialogue.Line: Were they all Chinese?
Tong-wallahs. Criminals. The gutter scrapings of Shanghai.
And one midget.
Yes. My dear Doctor, how on Earth did you deduce that one of my attackers was a midget?
Elementary, my dear Litefoot. He came in the laundry basket and let the others in.
The same creature that attacked me!
The Peking Homunculus.
Who?
Yes, the time of manufacture, its disappearance, it all fits.
Doctor, what is the Peking
Homunculus.
Homunculus.
It was made in Peking for the Commissioner of the Icelandic Alliance. It was in the Ice Age, about the year five thousand.
Preposterous.
Shush. Go on, Doctor.

The Peking Homunculus was a toy, a plaything for the Commissioner's children. It contained a series of magnetic fields operating on a printed circuit and a small computer. It had one organic component. The cerebral cortex of a pig. Anyway, something went wrong. It almost caused World War Six.
What?
Yes, somehow the pig part took over. So Weng-Chiang has brought the Peking Homunculus back through time. He could have done. It disappeared completely. It was never found.
I say, I may have had a bang on the head but this is a dashed queer story. Time travel?
Unsuccessful time travel, Professor. Findicker's discovery of the double nexus particle sent human science up a technological cul-de-sac.
Are you following this?
Not a word.

This pig thing is still alive. It needs an operator, of course, but the mental feedback is so intense that somehow the swinish instinct has become dominant. It hates humanity and it revels in carnage.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The coolies wheel in the cabinet, then kow-tow to Weng and Sin, who are in front of a large golden dragon.

Dialogue.Line: Liberation, Mister Sin! Freedom! I can become whole again. Whole and alive! Oh, how I have dreamt of this moment. To be free of this putrefying carcass, to fashion myself anew in some distant time and place. And I can do it now, now that at last I have the time cabinet. I promise you, Mister Sin, we shall not remain long among these filthy barbarians. But where is the bag? Answer me, you fools! Where is the bag?
It was. We did not.
The bag, you cowering oaf!
It was left behind, great lord.
What? What! Lee! Lee, I told you to take it out to the carriage! I ordered you! You know the penalty for failing me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Weng takes a pill box out and opens it, then holds it out to Cheng's assistant.

Dialogue.Line: Take the sting of the scorpion.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The terrified man obeys, and dies in agony while Weng and Sin laugh.
The Doctor reads the Limehouse laundry label.

Dialogue.Line: Rundall Buildings.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Causeway, Limehouse.

Dialogue.Line: What?
Your laundry. Do you know the place?
I've heard of it. Everyone has. It's the centre of one of the most noxious and evil rookeries in the East End.
And where exactly is this disreputable quarter?
It lies somewhere between Whitechapel and St Georges in the East. Place of appalling vice and squalor. Overdue for clearance in my opinion.
Yes, it might be cleared very quickly.
What do you mean?
Weng-Chiang is a scientific ignoramus. He doesn't understand the nature of zigma energy.
Zigma energy?
Yes. The power source of the time cabinet is a zigma beam. At the moment it's like a piece of elastic fully stretched, but when Chiang tampers with it
Then he must be stopped. Do you think he's gone to this laundry?
Well, there's only one way to find out. Litefoot, I want you to stay here. Come on.
Doctor, you can't take a young woman into that foulness. At this hour of night she'll witness the vilest scenes of depravity and degradation.
Nothing as vile as Weng-Chiang himself, Professor.

Think large, Henry Jago, think large. Shilling a head? I must be crazy. A guinea a head! Conducted tours round the lair of the phantom. I'll lead them myself and modestly mention the part I played in the affair. The ladies will swoon in my arms. Oh, it's a winner. It's a beauty. I'll go bail. I'll clear out all this old junk, call in the electric lighting company.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He finds Weng's carpet bag.

Dialogue.Line: What in the name of heavens is?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A hand reaches out from the trapdoor to the laboratory and Jago retreats.
The Doctor opens a skylight and Leela jumps into the hamper room.

Dialogue.Line: Not a sound. Now quiet. Shush.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor knocks over a pile of wicker hampers.
Litefoot is sweeping up the shards of a broken vase when there is a hammering at the front door. He goes to answer it still holding the dustpan and brush.

Dialogue.Line: Thank you. Kindly tell your employer that Mister Jago wishes to see him urgently.
What?
Your employer, Professor Litefoot. Come along, man. Hurry. Chop-chop.
May I ask, sir, who you are?
Confound your insolence, sir. Just announce me.
Consider yourself announced, sir. I'm Litefoot.
Why, dash me optics. I should have realised. That brow, those hands. England's peerless premier professor of pathology. Henry Gordon Jago, sir, at your service.
Mister Jago, just tell me what all this is about.
The Doctor.
What?
This bag.
Eh?
Shall we go inside?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Litefoot picks up a stout walking stick and follows Jago in.

Dialogue.Line: Found this in my cellar. Thought the Doctor might be interested. It could have something to do with those Chineses.
Chinese?
Yes. I had thought of communicating directly with Scotland Yard, where as you know he's held in the highest esteem.
The Doctor is?
Oh yes, of course. It's my opinion he solves half their cases and then lets them take the credit for it, don't you agree?
I have no idea.

Oh, why, it stands to reason. I mean, they're policemen. We all know they're solid, sterling, fellows, but their buttons are the brightest thing about them, don't you agree? Now, the Doctor's a real detective.
Yes, he's certainly very active. How did you learn of my connection with him, Mister Jago?

Well, I enquired at the local station and they told me you'd been seen together. The most formidable combination in the annals of criminology. It's a great honour and privilege for me to be working with you on this devilish affair.
Oh, well, thank you. Yes, well, I'm sure the Doctor will be very interested in these things. Unfortunately, he isn't here at present.
I know, the sleuth that never rests, eh?
Well, he did remark that sleep is for tortoises. You know, Mister Jago, I can't for the life of me discern what purposes these articles might serve.
It's a queer lot of paraphernalia. I thought so meself.
And you think they were set aside by Weng-Chiang, this murderous lunatic the Doctor is now hunting?
Well, they're nothing to do with the theatre, I'm sure of that. I found the bag amongst a pile of our old junk.
In that case, Mister Jago, is it not possible that someone plans to return for it?
Yes, yes, good point. We must tell the Doctor.
Or take a hand ourselves.
Why?
Well, the Doctor isn't here. If you and I keep a discreet watch on the theatre, we might get a chance to nab this fellow, should he return.
You're suggesting a pernoctation, Professor, but alas, unfortunately the nocturnal vapours are very bad for my chest.
Oh, come on, man, you can wrap up. I'll lend you some extra clothing.
Very kind, I'm sure.
Now, you write a note to the Doctor, you'll find pen and paper in that drawer, and I'll look you out a cape. We might be lucky, Mister Jago. And if we are, I've a few lumps to repay.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor slides a piece of paper under the attic door then pushes the key out of the lock onto it and brings it back into the room. He unlocks the door and they go through into a room with several small beds in it.

Dialogue.Line: That smell. It's like decaying fruit.
Papaver somniferum.
What?
Pipe of poppy. It's opium, a narcotic drug.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He goes through a curtain, then another.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, we've found another warren. Weng-Chiang will show his hand again.
More girls?
Yes. He'll try to build his body levels before he has to use the zigma beam. He'll kill again tonight, but where?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Through yet another curtain, a familiar figure is lying on a bed smoking opium to deaden the pain.

Dialogue.Line: At the House of the Dragon, Doctor.
Good evening, Mister Chang. We thought you'd gone to join your ancestors.
Not yet. Not quite.
Your leg!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There is only the one, and a bloody stump next to it.

Dialogue.Line: A singular sight, I fear. It is too late, Doctor, and I feel no pain. The opium.
How did you get away?
When the rat took my leg, I regained consciousness in a charnel house, putrefying human remains.
Yes, rats don't keep a very hygienic larder.

I lay there, Doctor, and cursed Weng-Chiang, my benefactor, who had brought me to this fate. Hatred of him gave me the strength to drag myself away. The rats had gone. I came here to destroy the false god. The last act of the Great Chang.
You should have done that before.
I believed in him. For many years I believed in him.
It was a good act, Chang.
Until he shamed me. I lost face. The whole theatre saw my failure.
Tell me about the House of the Dragon.
Next month, the Great Chang would have performed before the Queen Empress at Buckingham Palace. I, the son of a peasant.
The House of the Dragon, where is it?
It is his fortress, prepared over many months by the Tong. Beware the eye of the dragon, Doctor.
Li H'sen, come on. Come on.
Soon I shall join my ancestors. Already I can see them. They walk to greet me from the Palace of Jade. They are smiling and carry gifts of food and flowers. Now I cross the golden bridge of the gods.
Li H'sen! Come on, man, the house.
B, B
What? What?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chang reaches down and touches the Doctor's boot, then dies.

Dialogue.Line: Boot? Shoe? Spat?
Earth?
He's left us a Chinese puzzle.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Four coolies enter and kneel.

Dialogue.Line: Well? Where is it?
Bag not there, lord. It's gone.
Gone?
We look all places. Bag not there.

You incompetent lice! You crawling, mindless dogs! That bag contained the key to the time cabinet. I must have it, do you understand, if I have to tear this accursed city apart stone by stone! Ho! Were you followed?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Weng looks out of a window down on two gentlemen in top hats standing across the road. One wears a red silk lined cape.

Dialogue.Line: Followed? What?
Those two. They must have been watching the theatre. That means they have the bag! Bring them to me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ho issues orders in Chinese.

Scenes.Scene: Outside the House of the Dragon

Dialogue.Line: This is their hideaway, no doubt about it.
It's unfortunate there were too many of them for us to tackle, eh, Professor? I was itching for a scrap.
The question is, Mister Jago, what now?
Well, we could adjourn for liquid refreshment. Decorate the mahogany. I know a little spot not far from here.
I think one of us should stay here on watch while the other returns for the Doctor.
Good idea. I'll be as quick as I can.
Too late, old man.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Four coolies are approaching, bearing weapons.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, corks.
Backs to the wall.
Keep off, you lot. I'm a tiger when my dander's up.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jago and Litefoot are hustled in.

Dialogue.Line: So, you choose to pry on the House of the Dragon. Unwise. Very unwise. You will suffer for it.
You're mistaken. You'll be the sufferer when the police get here.
The police? Did you hear that, Mister Sin? They take me for a simpleton.
Oh, they'll be here, don't you worry. They can't be far behind.
